author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet the guidelines for auto-merging. Please make sure that you have read the [General registry README](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/blob/master/README.md) and the [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). The following guidelines were not met:

- There is no compat entry for `julia`.
- The following dependencies do not have a `[compat]` entry that is upper-bounded and only includes a finite number of breaking releases: DifferentialEquations, Distributions, Integrals, Roots

Note that the guidelines are only required for the pull request to be merged automatically. However, it is **strongly recommended** to follow them, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

After you have fixed the AutoMerge issues, simply retrigger Registrator, which will automatically update this pull request. You do not need to change the version number in your `Project.toml` file (unless of course the AutoMerge issue is that you skipped a version number, in which case you should change the version number).

If you do not want to fix the AutoMerge issues, please post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. Then, send a message to the `#pkg-registration` channel in the [Julia Slack](https://julialang.org/slack/) to ask for help. Include a link to this pull request.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have also read the package naming guidelines: https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->
Hi, congrats on the new package! Could I suggest a more specific name, perhaps related to survival analysis? The current one is very broad

> Hi, congrats on the new package! Could I suggest a more specific name, perhaps related to survival analysis? The current one is very broad

Sure.
Some background: It exports the type `JointModel` which scientist would interact with. So the plural was just the naming convention given by the Julia. 
There is also the abstract type `HazardBasedDistribution` which contains some computations and provides the basis for joint models. I dont see any applications for this besides joint models thus i did not like it as the title of the package.

> It exports the type JointModel which scientist would interact with. So the plural was just the naming convention given by the Julia.

Indeed but when people `import` your package, they know what they're doing with the types inside it. The package name on the other hand can be misleading if someone is looking for a specific functionality outside of your domain.

Maybe `JointSurvivalModels.jl`?

> Indeed but when people `import` your package, they know what they're doing with the types inside it. The package name on the other hand can be misleading if someone is looking for a specific functionality outside of your domain.

> Maybe JointSurvivalModels.jl?

What do you think @danielinteractive ? It looks a bit strange to split the term `joint model` but somehow also makes scence and sounds okey.

Would you @gdalle  then also want to change the type name and along that the docs, tests, comments etc.? I understand your concern, but it seems like quite a bit of work.
I think the term "joint model" is indeed a bit general. In our domain people might understand it but outside I don't think so. So yeah the proposal makes sense
can be closed in favor of #101247

> Would you @gdalle then also want to change the type name and along that the docs, tests, comments etc.? I understand your concern, but it seems like quite a bit of work.

I think a find-and-replace of `JointModels` => `JointSurvivalModels` in the entire repo should do the trick!
thank you for taking my remark into account ;)

body:

title: New package: JointModels v0.3.0
